title: Money Recognition for the Visually Impaired: A Case Study on Sri Lankan Banknotes
author: Akshaan Bandara (Informatics Institute of Technology, Colombo, Sri Lanka)
relevance_why: This paper discusses a method for real-time currency recognition, which employs deep learning techniques that could inspire analogous applications in audio generation or enhancement, such as analyzing audio cues or signals.
background: This study aims to develop a mobile application that helps visually impaired individuals identify Sri Lankan banknotes using an object detection model trained on a custom dataset.
contribution: This research introduces a user-friendly currency recognition system using a fine-tuned EfficientDet model to solve the identification challenges faced by visually impaired individuals, achieving an average precision of 0.9847.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods for currency recognition often lacked user-friendly interfaces and were not optimized for real-time performance, limiting their practical application for visually impaired users.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves by implementing a lightweight, efficient object detection model tailored for mobile use, ensuring accurate real-time currency identification without needing internet connectivity.

key_innovation: The use of a scalable object detection model that allows for accurate real-time currency recognition, focusing on ease of use for visually impaired users.
real_world_impact: This application significantly enhances the independence and security of visually impaired users during financial transactions by allowing them to identify banknotes accurately and quickly.
limitations: The system struggles with low visibility conditions at night and experiences slight delays in prediction due to video feed processing.

new_terms.EfficientDet: **EfficientDet** is a family of scalable object detection models that optimize accuracy and efficiency for various applications, primarily on mobile devices.
